title: Bagalakote
description:
N. Jagannatha Prakash Aihole and Pattadakal, acclaimed as the cradle of Indian sculpture; Badami, which pioneered cave temples on this soil. Badami, blossomed amidst unimaginably sculpted rocks. Bagalakote, once part of Vijayapura district, holds within it a wealth of such remarkable tourist destinations.
Bagalakote shares an umbilical bond with the historically illustrious Vijayapura. It is a region of great historical significance, once ruled by the Chalukyas and Rashtrakutas.
Majestic rocky outcrops, clusters of natural caves, and the enchanting vistas of valleys all of these shaping temples of timeless beauty. Along with ponds, waterfalls, and sacred pilgrim centres, they enrich the tourism wealth that Bagalakote district proudly holds.
Aihole is home to over two hundred temples, each showcasing rich sculptural variety. Among its attractions are the Durga Devi Temple, Lad Khan Temple, a Buddhist Chaitya hall (Chaityalaya), and the Meguti Temple built by Ravikirti. The caves here also house shrines of various faiths, making Aihole a major draw for visitors.
Pattadakal, listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is renowned for its temples representing major styles of Indian architecture. It has also earned fame for its splendid group of temples.
Badami, once the capital of the Chalukya kings and historically known as Vatapi, is famed for its cave temples. The caves here, housing Shaiva, Vaishnava, and Jain shrines, are marvels of exquisite rock-cut architecture.
Badamis spectacular charm lies in its clusters of rocky boulders. It is a natural arena for adventure sports and has served as a favoured outdoor location for several films.
Nestled in the lap of nature, Banashankari is one of North Karnatakas foremost pilgrimage centres. It is also among the sites where one of Indias longest fairs is held. Banashankari, which showcases the charm of natural beauty, bursts into grandeur during Sankranti. The Banashankari fair is also a vibrant stage for professional theatre troupes from across the region, with plays running for weeks together.
Mahakuta, set amidst picturesque hillocks, is a cluster of temples that captivate devotees and visitors alike. The site is especially known for its group of Shivalingas, which are a sight to behold, and the sacred temple tank (pushkarani) here adds to its charm.
Kudalasangama, where the Krishna and Malaprabha rivers merge, is a revered site. Attractions here include the Sangamanatha Temple, the Aikya Mantapa (sacred memorial) of Basavanna, and the Basava International Centre.
Bagalakote, which nurtured extraordinary architecture in the cradle of nature, is equally blessed with scenic natural sites. The majestic falls at Didaga near Gulegudda, the Siddanakolla and Haluhande waterfalls, and the herds of chinkara deer spotted in the forested hill tracts of Bilagi taluk stand as striking examples.
Among the first to resist the British attempts to bring India under their control were the valiant Halagali Bedas of Mudhol in Bagalakote. In honour of their supreme sacrifice for the nations defence, a national memorial has been built at Halagali.
Mudhol is also home to the breeding and preservation centre for the indigenous Mudhol hounds, which have earned a place in the Indian Armys canine squad.
Once known in ancient times as Jambukhanagari, Jamakhandi was a princely state ruled by the Patawardhan family. After Independence, it was the very first princely state to merge with the Indian Republic. The Patawardhan royal residence, the Ramteertha Palace, remains a graceful architectural landmark of Jamakhandi.
In Savalagi of Jamkhandi taluk, the Someshwara temple built during the Kalyana Chalukya period is remarkable for a rare phenomenon: on the day of Yugadi, the suns rays fall directly upon the Shiva Linga.
Herakallu, within the Bilagi region, is a site of prehistoric remains from the Stone Age. It houses temples of Mallikarjuna, Lokuravva, and Yalagureshwara. Flowing nearby, the Ghataprabha river has carved striking patterns into the rocks of the hill, earning it the name Beelekallu Loka.
Ilakal, renowned for its red granite, is equally famous for its handwoven Ilakal sarees, which enjoy a special place in Karnatakas cultural heritage.
The Almatti reservoir, built across the Krishna river, has become a major attraction with its landscaped gardens, exhibition hall, and bird sanctuary in the backwaters. Adding to the districts charm are the granite quarries of Gulegudda, the renowned Ilakal saree industry, temples inscribed with Vachanas, the Lakshminarasimha temple of Shurpali, and the celebrated inscription of Kappe Arabhatta at Badami. With such diverse attractions, Bagalakote has every potential to delight as one of Karnatakas prominent tourist destinations.
author: Stories in Sculputure, Grandeur
